name: NPR
text: RT @tamarakeithNPR: The White House is on lockdown. The photo below is the door to the briefing room. (I’m stuck inside with many of the press corps finest) There is an intense protest across the street in Lafayette Park. https://t.co/BOfrVL9oL7The White House is on lockdown. The photo below is the door to the briefing room. (I’m stuck inside with many of th… https://t.co/jrN5eAZxEX

name: NPR
text: The U.S. Department of Justice is siding with campground and restaurant owners in Maine who sued the state over a two-week self-quarantine policy for out-of-state visitors. https://t.co/5TaN7bKl9h

name: NPR
text:
Minneapolis paid out $3 million dollars to settle a lawsuit over the 2010 death of David Smith. 

The young black man died after an officer pinned him down with a knee on his back for several minutes.
https://t.co/mjJE4qE2Sy

name: NPR
text:
President Trump says he is severing U.S. ties — and funding — to the WHO over its response to China's handling of the coronavirus epidemic.

Experts say it's questionable whether he can unilaterally make that decision.
https://t.co/weRtiVKjH9

name: NPR
text:
UNESCO and the Vatican agree present-day Jordan is where Jesus' baptism is believed to have taken place. 

But across the river, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, there is a rival spot collecting millions of dollars in tourism revenue.
https://t.co/L5cv14f5Ja

name: NPR
text:
D Smoke, winner of Netflix's "Rhythm + Flow," performed for his first-ever Tiny Desk Home Concert. 

His songs, from his album "Black Habits," acknowledge the disparities impacting the black experience that are simultaneously personal and universal. https://t.co/IgSsMBxqXb

name: NPR
text: Superstar pitcher Max Scherzer, a leader of the MLB players' union, says the league had "no justification" for asking its players to take another pay cut -- up to 80 percent for the highest-paid. @wamu885 https://t.co/Rs0F8XshXj

name: NPR
text: Tracee Ellis Ross discusses fulfilling a life-long dream of singing, gate-keeping in the music industry and what her mom, singer Diana Ross, thinks of her latest endeavor. https://t.co/QH8pBdaUaw

name: NPR
text: RT @adrianflorido: A fire spreading through a car lot as people frantically try to get the cars out. Minneapolis. https://t.co/6tLixZee5o

name: NPR
text: Anger over George Floyd's death is reverberating across the U.S., with protests from New York City to Los Angeles. https://t.co/75O8NolXAR

name: NPR
text:
French officials looked at 3 factors in making their decision to begin lifting pandemic restrictions, Prime Minister Édouard Philippe said:

1) the circulation of the coronavirus
2) the number of available ICU beds
3) testing capacity https://t.co/ncxkdxd87c

name: NPR
text:
In Atlanta, a crowd of protesters outside of an entrance to CNN's headquarters repeatedly threw rocks at officers attempting to keep them from rushing into the building.

Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp issued a state of emergency around midnight. https://t.co/mlq8PkFGyZ

name: NPR
text:
In this edition of our Alone Together Duets series, singer and songwriter Becca Stevens' brooding composition "I Will Avenge You" gets a violin-laced face-lift from her husband, Nathan Schram, a violist for Attacca Quartet.

Apologies to their neighbors. https://t.co/8zxKsj0kRY

name: NPR
text: The pandemic has largely eclipsed the conversation around the opioid crisis. But it still rages on despite business closures, the cancellation of in-person treatment appointments and the strain on addiction resources. https://t.co/418OnpUnKk

name: NPR
text:
Video games — even the non-educational kind — can help kids get interested in learning. Just ask our video gaming columnist, who once aced a pop quiz on the Caribbean thanks to her "Assasin's Creed" habit.
https://t.co/0AHNWqVqvp

name: NPR
text:
Review: Mikel Jollett's memoir shows that those who grow up in families with addiction can find a way to self-reliance and sustainable meaning. 

But more importantly, it shows that the pain is the constant. Overcoming it is managing it. https://t.co/87wVYpibc3

name: NPR
text:
At least one person was killed in Detroit as protests continue nationwide over George Floyd's death. 

In Minnesota, the National Guard has prepared to deploy 1,700 soldiers – the largest deployment in the state's history. https://t.co/LZ2L4isIOb

name: NPR
text:
A group of House Democrats introduced a bill that would grant the U.S. Census Bureau's request to delay major deadlines for delivering results of the 2020 census because of the pandemic.
https://t.co/WkoOMBXE6F

name: NPR
text:
While researching his book "Breath," James Nestor participated in a study in which his nose was plugged for 10 days — forcing him to breathe solely through his mouth.

"My stress levels were off the charts. My nervous system was a mess. ... I felt awful." https://t.co/tyBgHqjCEW

name: NPR
text: In Afghanistan, an all-girls robotics team is trying to build a mechanized, hand-operated ventilator for coronavirus patients — using parts from old Toyota Corollas. https://t.co/hJ5M22370c

name: NPR
text: Pro athletes: They are definitely not just like us. That's what Boston Globe sports writer Nora Princiotti discovered when she tried a 10-minute sprinting session designed for football players. "It was horrible," she told @WBUR. "I'm never doing it again." https://t.co/9N3ybB9erq

name: NPR
text: The COVID-19 pandemic will go down in history. But most of us won't remember our experience that well. Short Wave explores what memory research says we will and won't recall about living through this moment – and why some may remember more than others. https://t.co/XorU1dtosU

name: NPR
text:
A second person was killed Friday night in a shooting at the Ronald V. Dellums Federal Building in Oakland, Calif. 

The FBI said that person was a a contract security officer for the Federal Protective Service. https://t.co/lcmmOTlUhl

name: NPR
text: Planes, trains and automobiles: Which is better for mitigating your coronavirus risk if you have to travel? https://t.co/9DBEO5Olrz

name: NPR
text: Though data gaps remain, the pattern is clear: Communities of color are being hit disproportionately by COVID-19. https://t.co/y3vUJ99pug

name: NPR
text:
"We know that these racial ethnic disparities in COVID-19 are the result of pre-pandemic realities," a health equity researcher says.

"It's a legacy of structural discrimination that has limited access to health and wealth for people of color." https://t.co/hIrAWZgf9E https://t.co/6PS6V0tbY5

name: NPR
text:
The Supreme Court has rejected a California church's attempt to overturn the state's coronavirus restrictions on in-person religious services.
https://t.co/P3I3jkkbFR

name: NPR
text:
President Trump's new rallying cry in his war against Twitter — "REVOKE 230!" — refers to a section of the Communications Decency Act that says online platforms aren't liable for what users post.

Without it, experts warn there'd be more censorship online. https://t.co/JYmPy5X3GC

name: NPR
text: RT @rdlewis: SpaceX And NASA Try Once More To Launch Astronauts Today. Our team: @gbrumfiel, @nell_sci_NPR and @spacebrendan)  https://t.co/EFoHrllr3Y

name: NPR
text:
New Zealand is now down to only one active COVID-19 case. The last time a new case was reported in the country was over a week ago. 

No one is currently hospitalized with the disease. https://t.co/S3LoZ7Y5Tb

name: NPR
text:
The American Postal Workers Union president says the Postal Service may run out of cash by early fall without relief from Congress — which the Trump administration opposes.

That would jeopardize mail-in voting at a time more voters are turning toward it. https://t.co/4ga3nQDpCW

name: NPR
text:
As we learn more about the virus, it's possible the guidance related to air conditioning systems may change. But for now, an infectious disease specialist says it's not a primary concern for the spread of COVID-19. 
https://t.co/1V61irO8Sz

name: NPR
text:
RT @hereandnow: Tips for reducing food waste at home:

🌽Make a list of what you need to buy before going to the grocery store.
🍎Store food correctly.
🥦Freeze food you’re not ready to use.
🍇If it tastes, smells and looks good, don’t worry about the use by date. https://t.co/0R18GdsJjx

name: NPR
text:
NASA astronauts Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken will travel to the International Space Station aboard SpaceX's Dragon capsule. 

They're scheduled to lift off at 3:22 p.m. Watch here 👇
https://t.co/9MP7u0vJHl

name: NPR
text:
Faced with a fifth straight night of protests over the death of George Floyd, Gov. Tim Walz says he's fully mobilizing the state's National Guard — "an action that has never been taken in [the guard's] 164-year history."
https://t.co/LipCsQvvo0

name: NPR
text:
Hazard pay is ending for many essential workers, whose wages — with the temporary raises — are lower than federal unemployment benefits. 

That's why advocates argue that the pay bumps should be made permanent. https://t.co/0IKi78NtHs

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: SpaceX's Dragon capsule has successfully reached orbit. It's on its way to the International Space Station… https://t.co/UOSXc9u2IL

name: NPR
text: RT @JamilSmith: You can hear my voice on the new episode of @NPRCodeSwitch, reading a column that I wrote five years ago about the videos that show us black death, over and over again, and speaking a bit about how little has changed in America. Please give it a listen. https://t.co/kkUnAJKxWA

name: NPR
text:
"I can't breathe." — Eric Garner, July 2014

"I can't breathe." — George Floyd, May 25, 2020

We're at the point where the verbiage people use to plead for their lives can be repurposed as shorthand for completely separate tragedies.
https://t.co/2642n6dUNx

name: NPR
text:
Margaret Sullivan, 85, says she found her brother's name halfway down the first column of the New York Times' front page marking the 100,000 lives lost to COVID-19 in the U.S.

"For Ted, they said that he 'could make anything grow.' And he could." https://t.co/nagT3NLjjr

name: NPR
text:
Commentary: Linda Lombardi knew that her former patient had no family or close friends. So she used FaceTime to stay with her during her final hours in a special palliative care ward for COVID-19 patients. 

"I just couldn't let her die alone," she says.
https://t.co/dqcbW6Rl0k

name: NPR
text: The Pentagon has ordered as many as 800 military police to prepare to deploy to Minnesota if Gov. Tim Walz requests it, a U.S. official tells NPR. https://t.co/VxhawGrqr9

name: NPR
text:
Americans are continuing to express their grief and outrage over the death of George Floyd in demonstrations across U.S., with violence emerging in some cities. 
https://t.co/TnxQpGdUu4

name: NPR
text:
Mike Pence’s chief of staff owns as much as $1.6 million worth of stocks in companies linked to coronavirus response.

He declared some to be possible conflicts of interest but hasn't divested from them.

"This is now a red alarm," said an ethics watchdog. https://t.co/XDLNy4a3aS
